body:
Good question. First of all: If the repository variable isn't updated, it won't result in a broken build, but just in a less 'optimal' one. I tested that (locally) by removing all the Horton works repos from the variable.
Maven will then fallback to the remote repo.

My best suggestion for keeping this list updated will be grepping the build log for any non-local downloads afterwards. Maybe some periodic check in Jenkins?

Epic oneliner (to run in separate jenkins alert job or something):
```
[[ $(grep "Downloading from" ~/bigtop/build.txt | grep -v "Downloading from default" | wc -l ) = "0" ]] && echo "Build contains external repositories that are not added to 'repos'-variable in build.gradle. Please consider updating the variable."
```

@cheelio I tested your change with a debian-11 Docker image and it works great, I can see the nexus container showing up logs of requests and its cache storage growing as the builds proceed. I tried with a build of hive (note: I overrode the dh_strip_determinism step in the rules files since it is a step that takes ages) and it took ~12 mins on my laptop with an empty cache, ~6 mins with cache warmed up (basically an identical hive-clean hive-pkg executed afterwards). So this is really great!

I am trying to understand the nexus caching code in more details, so apologies if this question is trivial - is there a reason to have `configure-nexus-public-group` and `generate_nexus_tasks` initializing the same set of `repos` ?

The `generate_nexus_tasks` function creates `configure-nexus-xxxxxx` gradle tasks for each `repo` in `repos`. These tasks create a proxy repository in Nexus.

The (new) `configure-nexus-public-group` gradle task is executed after the individual `configure-nexus-xxxxxx` nexus tasks and create/update the `public` repository group in nexus so that this group consists of all the individual proxy's in `repos`. 

Finally, the `configure-nexus` task is the entry point. Because of the dependants, it will always first create/overwritte the proxy repo's followed by updating the group repo.

The task itself will write a settings.xml file pointing to the `public` group repo.  The `mirrorOf`-attribute contains a  comma separated string with repo IDs. These will match with the repo IDs in the individual `pom.xml` files.

 In this way, when a new repository is added somewhere in a in a (new) module that isn't (yet) included in the `repos` variable, it will not be proxied by nexus to make sure the build will not fail.

@cheelio thanks a lot for the detailed explanation, would it be ok for you to add comments to the code that you modified so everybody will be on the same page when reading `build.gradle`? As far as I can see there is not a lot of knowledge about how Nexus works, and your experience would be really appreciated by future readers if written down properly :)
Something like that?
Yep LGTM! @oflebbe @sekikn I think that this change would be great even for the upcoming 3.0.1 release, lemme know what are your thoughts!

Hi @elukey  , please do what makes sense. The usage of the private repository  nexus-private raises airbrows  for me.
shouldn't we use http://repo.hortonworks.com/content/groups/public instead? .

The nexus-private repository seems to [come from Ambari](https://github.com/apache/ambari/blob/release-2.7.5/pom.xml#L135), and I'm not sure if Ambari is successfully built if we replace it with https://repo.hortonworks.com/content/groups/public/. I'll try it later.

The nexus-private repo was actually introduced in bigtop in  https://github.com/apache/bigtop/commit/ebbf2f763149da2132a055c11d00d41a4ca01eff.

I don't understand why, because in upstream ambari, it was changed to `https://repo.hortonworks.com/content/groups/public/` in https://github.com/apache/ambari/pull/3063/files/20caaf1404b8ed438c9a743e6dec03a36f2cb63f.

I tried to build Ambari 2.7.5 with a clean Maven local repository without private-nexus in any pom.xml and it succeeded.
As Olaf said, I also think we generally shouldn't use corporate private repository if it's not necessary, so would you update the PR with the following items @cheelio?

* Add a diff that replaces private-nexus with https://repo.hortonworks.com/content/groups/public/ into bigtop-packages/src/common/ambari/patch9-remove-not-working-plugin-repos.diff
* Remove the existing bigtop-packages/src/common/ambari/patch9-ambari-repo-change.diff introduced in BIGTOP-3607 (I think it may have been a temporary problem caused by a intermittent failure of the Hortonworks public repository, and its fix is not necessary now)
* Remove the private-nexus entry from the repos variable in build.gradle

Once updated, I'll merge this into branch-3.0 and master.
BIGTOP-3607 is a temporary solution for Ambari dependencies download error. I think we should remove the patch file.

@sekikn @oflebbe @elukey   
Ok, I got two flavours:

First commit has everything you asked for.
Second commit removes all 'dependencies' to Hortonworks repositories. I think I sleep much better at night, knowing that this build will always succeed, even if Cloudera decides to shutdown all their public Nexus repositories. I guess that could be a serious scenario.
What I had to do to make that work is removing the `ambari-metrics-storm-sink-legacy` module from the project. This module contains references 'backtype.storm.metric.IClusterReporter' which only seems available in `org.apache.storm:storm-core:0.10.0.2.3.0.0-2557`. Sources of this interface aren't available anywhere online. By removing `ambari-metrics-storm-sink-legacy` (I think the word 'legacy' tells me that it won't hurt that much), as a module from the build, I can eliminiate *all* references to Hortonworks Nexus repositories from ambari.

Let me know what you think!
Oh, and another thing that I had to do was changing the pom version of af bunch of modules from from 1.0.0.0-SNAPSHOT to 2.7.5.0.

@cheelio Thanks for updating! I agree to remove the ambari-metrics-storm-sink-legacy module and dependencies on the Hortonworks repository, because that module seems to support before Storm 1.0, which was released more than five years ago. In addition, Bigtop doesn't provide Storm as its component. Give me a few days to try to build and run Ambari with your PR.
@cheelio I left some comments on the latest PR. Would you address them during my trial?
Now that Ambari is building smoothly, I will start working on creating a bigtop 3.0.0 mpack.
thanks @iwasakims!

+1, I ran `./gradlew allclean ambari-pkg-ind -Pnexus=true` twice with a nexus container set up in the same node and confirmed

* the package was successfully built
* .m2/settings.xml was properly configured
* the second run was about 2.3 times faster than the first (22m45s -> 9m43s)
Merged into master and branch-3.0. Thanks a lot @cheelio!
Thanks! Merged into master and branch-3.0.
Thanks! Merged into master and branch-3.0.
Thanks! Merged into master and branch-3.0.

I found that only this PR leads to a build failure on Debian or Ubuntu.
(This problem may be specific for our CI environment, because we're doing some tricky things to avoid the uid inconsistency between host and docker container)

https://ci.bigtop.apache.org/view/Releases/job/Bigtop-3.0.1/12/DISTRO=debian-10,PLATFORM=ppc64le-slave/console
https://ci.bigtop.apache.org/view/Releases/job/Bigtop-3.0.1/12/DISTRO=ubuntu-18.04,PLATFORM=ppc64le-slave/console
https://ci.bigtop.apache.org/view/Releases/job/Bigtop-3.0.1/12/DISTRO=ubuntu-20.04,PLATFORM=ppc64le-slave/console

```
+ '[' powerpc64le = powerpc64le ']'
+ mvn install:install-file -DgroupId=io.grpc -DartifactId=protoc-gen-grpc-java -Dversion=1.28.0 -Dclassifier=linux-ppcle_64 -Dpackaging=exe -Dfile=/usr/src/grpc-java-1.28.0/compiler/build/exe/java_plugin/protoc-gen-grpc-java
[ERROR] Could not create local repository at /root/.m2/repository -> [Help 1]

...

[ERROR] [Help 1] http://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/LocalRepositoryNotAccessibleException
make[1]: *** [debian/rules:31: override_dh_auto_build] Error 1
make[1]: Leaving directory '/ws/output/alluxio/alluxio-2.4.1'
make: *** [debian/rules:27: binary] Error 2
dpkg-buildpackage: error: fakeroot debian/rules binary subprocess returned exit status 2
debuild: fatal error at line 1182:
dpkg-buildpackage -us -uc -ui -b
 failed

> Task :alluxio-deb FAILED

FAILURE: Build failed with an exception.
```

I'm going to submit an addendum PR for it.
Thanks! Merged into master and branch-3.0.
Oh, I've just noticed the same fix had already been submitted as #852. I'll close this PR and review that instead.

```
   --disable-gpg-check \
   --stack hdfs,yarn,mapreduce,hbase,hive,spark \
   --smoke-tests hdfs,yarn,mapreduce,hbase,hive,spark
```

Merged into master. Thanks @iwasakims!

@sekikn `./gradlew hadoop-pkg-ind` did not work. The cause seems to be that there is no /sbin/init in the image. Can you address the issue here?

```
$ ./gradlew hadoop-pkg-ind -POS=fedora-35 -Pprefix=trunk
...
++ docker run -d bigtop/slaves:trunk-fedora-35 /sbin/init
+ CONTAINER_ID=f84bd35ba9b3042770ad93fda27dafbf4bd823b9fe7424d6ab963f6199777c85
+ trap 'docker rm -f f84bd35ba9b3042770ad93fda27dafbf4bd823b9fe7424d6ab963f6199777c85' EXIT
+ docker cp /home/fedora/srcs/bigtop f84bd35ba9b3042770ad93fda27dafbf4bd823b9fe7424d6ab963f6199777c85:/bigtop
+ docker cp /home/fedora/srcs/bigtop/bigtop-ci/entrypoint.sh f84bd35ba9b3042770ad93fda27dafbf4bd823b9fe7424d6ab963f6199777c85:/bigtop/entrypoint.sh
+ docker exec f84bd35ba9b3042770ad93fda27dafbf4bd823b9fe7424d6ab963f6199777c85 bash -c 'chown -R jenkins:jenkins /bigtop'
Error response from daemon: Container f84bd35ba9b3042770ad93fda27dafbf4bd823b9fe7424d6ab963f6199777c85 is not running
...
```

Thanks for the comment @iwasakims. I tested the PR on a VM instead of a Docker container, so I missed it. I updated the PR.

Currently, we have to run the *-ind tasks with the following options in case of Fedora 35, which systemctl requires them. I'd like to address it as another issue.

```
./gradlew allclean zookeeper-pkg-ind -POS=fedora-35 -Pdocker-run-option="--tmpfs /run --tmpfs /tmp --cgroupns=host -v /sys/fs/cgroup:/sys/fs/cgroup:rw"
```
Thanks! Merged into master and branch-3.0.

I removed `-Dslf4j.version=1.7.25` from MVN_ARGS to solve the following error. It was set for HBase 1.5.0 by BIGTOP-3297. It is useless now.

```
[WARNING] The POM for org.slf4j:slf4j-reload4j:jar:1.7.25 is missing, no dependency information available
```

Recent slf4j-log4j12 artifact is automatically replaced by slf4j-reload4j.
https://www.slf4j.org/news.html

We seem to have `AutoReq: no` in the SPEC as a workaround for the same issue.

```
$ find . -name '*.spec' | xargs grep AutoReq
./bigtop-packages/src/rpm/ambari/SPECS/ambari.spec:AutoReqProv: no
./bigtop-packages/src/rpm/ambari/SPECS/ambari.spec:AutoReqProv: no
./bigtop-packages/src/rpm/ambari/SPECS/ambari.spec:AutoReqProv: no
./bigtop-packages/src/rpm/bigtop-ambari-mpack/SPECS/bigtop-ambari-mpack.spec:AutoReqProv: no
./bigtop-packages/src/rpm/gpdb/SPECS/gpdb.spec:AutoReqProv: %{autorequire}
./bigtop-packages/src/rpm/hadoop/SPECS/hadoop.spec:# to set AutoReq to no in order to minimize confusion. Not ideal, but seems to work.
./bigtop-packages/src/rpm/hadoop/SPECS/hadoop.spec:AutoReq: no
./bigtop-packages/src/rpm/hadoop/SPECS/hadoop.spec:AutoReq: no
./bigtop-packages/src/rpm/hadoop/SPECS/hadoop.spec:AutoReq: no
./bigtop-packages/src/rpm/kibana/SPECS/kibana.spec:AutoReqProv: no
./bigtop-packages/src/rpm/logstash/SPECS/logstash.spec:AutoReqProv: no
./bigtop-packages/src/rpm/ycsb/SPECS/ycsb.spec:AutoReq: no
./bigtop-packages/src/rpm/zeppelin/SPECS/zeppelin.spec:AutoReq: no
```

The last commit was only for CentOS 7 because I got no dependency issue on Rocky Linux 8 and Fedora 35.

Smoke-tests of hbase succeeded on CentOS 7.
```
$ ./docker-hadoop.sh \
     --create 1 \
     --image bigtop/puppet:trunk-centos-7 \
     --memory 16g \
     --enable-local-repo \
     --stack hdfs,yarn,mapreduce,hbase \
     --smoke-tests hbase
...(snip)

BUILD SUCCESSFUL in 5m 51s
36 actionable tasks: 9 executed, 27 up-to-date
```

I got no issue on building phoenix against HBase 2.4.11 and manual testing.

```
$ ./docker-hadoop.sh --create 1 --image bigtop/puppet:trunk-centos-7 --memory 16g --repo file:///bigtop-home/output --disable-gpg-check --stack hdfs,yarn,mapreduce,hbase
$ ./docker-hadoop.sh --exec 1 /bin/bash
# yum --setopt='tsflags=' install phoenix
# ln -s /usr/lib/phoenix/phoenix-server.jar /usr/lib/hbase/lib/phoenix-server.jar
# systemctl restart hbase-master hbase-regionserver
```

+1, successfully built HBase and the components which directly depends on it, and ran their smoke tests except for Phoenix using Docker provisioner on Rocky 8, Debian 10/11 and Ubuntu 18.04/20.04 (x86_64).
I merged this to master. Thanks, @sekikn.

I tested this by docker provisioner on Fedora 35.

```
$ ./docker-hadoop.sh \
     --create 3 \
     --docker-compose-yml docker-compose-cgroupv2.yml \
     --image bigtop/puppet:trunk-fedora-35 \
     --memory 8g \
     --enable-local-repo \
     --stack hdfs,yarn,mapreduce \
     --smoke-tests hdfs,yarn,mapreduce
...(snip)
BUILD SUCCESSFUL in 10m 47s
41 actionable tasks: 12 executed, 29 up-to-date
```
Maybe we can set the default value of `--docker-compose-yml` based on the platform. It should be addressed in another JIRA.

+1, built Hadoop with the PR and ran the smoke test with the following commands on CentOS 7, Rocky 8 and Fedora 35. Thanks!

```
./docker-hadoop.sh -d -k hdfs,yarn -r file:///bigtop-home/output/ -s yarn -i bigtop/puppet:trunk-centos-7 -G -c 1
./docker-hadoop.sh -d -k hdfs,yarn -r file:///bigtop-home/output/ -s yarn -i bigtop/puppet:trunk-rockylinux-8 -G -c 1
./docker-hadoop.sh -d -k hdfs,yarn -r file:///bigtop-home/output/ -s yarn -i bigtop/puppet:trunk-fedora-35 -F docker-compose-cgroupv2.yml -G -c 1
```
I merged this. Thanks, @sekikn.

JIRA issue said that users have to add `--tmpfs /run --tmpfs /tmp --cgroupns=host -v /sys/fs/cgroup:/sys/fs/cgroup:rw`.
To make the message simple, I chose  `--privileged` option.

Oops. The error is related to protoc 3.17.3. We need additional fix for ppc64le.

```
[^[[1;31mERROR^[[m] PROTOC FAILED: /ws/build/hbase/rpm/BUILD/hbase-2.4.11/hbase-protocol-shaded/target/protoc-plugins/protoc-3.17.3-linux-ppcle_64.exe: /lib64/ld64.so.2: version `GLIBC_2.22' not found (required by /ws/build/hbase/rpm/BUILD/hbase-2.4.11/hbase-protocol-shaded/target/protoc-plugins/protoc-3.17.3-linux-ppcle_64.exe)
```
The `internal.protobuf.version` was 3.5.1-1 on HBase 2.2.6. It is 3.17.3 on HBase 2.4.11 (by HBASE-24168 and HBASE-26541).
Since protobuf >= 3.7 supports ppc64le, I removed the protoc-3.5.1-add-support-for-ppc64le.patch in the latest commit.
@sekikn Could you try the latest patch on ppc64le machine in CI env? I do not have testing environment.
+1, ensured the PR also works on ppc64le. Thanks @iwasakims!
Merged into master and branch-3.1.

@iwasakims I've just noticed that we had to align the protobuf version in other places too (e.g., https://ci.bigtop.apache.org/view/Releases/job/Bigtop-3.1.0/5/DISTRO=centos-7,PLATFORM=ppc64le-slave/console). I'm going to submit another PR as an addendum.

I have to fix the use of `docker inspect --format '{{ .NetworkSettings.IPAddress }}'` in `docker-hadoop.sh`, which only works on the old yaml format.

Thanks for the contribution, @pageman.

Could you file a issue on ASF JIRA first? The title of pull request must be prefixed with the issue id like "BIGTOP-xxxx. Fix typo in README.". 
* https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/BIGTOP
* https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/bigtop/how+to+contribute

You also should avoid mentioning line number in the title since the code/docs are chaging.
This is a draft using Hadoop 2.10.2-RC0. I will update the bigtop.bom to use released artifacts later.

I built HBase 1.5.0, Hive 2.3.6, Spark 2.4.5 against Hadoop 2.10.2-RC0 and ran smoke-tests on CentOS 7 x86_64.

```
$ ./gradlew bigtop-groovy-pkg bigtop-jsvc-pkg bigtop-tomcat-pkg bigtop-utils-pkg zookeeper-pkg hadoop-pkg hbase-pkg hive-pkg spark-pkg repo

$ ./docker-hadoop.sh \
       --create 3 \
       --image bigtop/puppet:trunk-centos-7 \
       --memory 8g \
       --repo file:///bigtop-home/output \
       --disable-gpg-check \
       --stack hdfs,yarn,mapreduce,hbase,hive,spark \
       --smoke-tests hdfs,yarn,mapreduce,hbase,hive,spark
...
BUILD SUCCESSFUL in 17m 4s
55 actionable tasks: 20 executed, 35 up-to-date
```

I considered separating the kubernetes package from the others. However the officially distributed Spark package now includes kubernetes libraries by default.
https://spark.apache.org/downloads.html

Hadoop 2.10.2 was released.
https://lists.apache.org/thread/po0cmhrl6oyrh9sqy8hfldocw3vsqwrt

@vivostar Thanks for the contribution.

This patch can not be merged because it breaks the deployment on distros other than CentOS 7. We must take care of all supported distros at the same time in order to upgrade Puppet.

Thank you for your review and merge.
FYI, here is an example for separating packages.
https://github.com/yoda-mon/bigtop/commit/0c03b7e59438ec1ac3cd326deeaedde71794c065
